Swallow woodpecker (heavy drinker, alcoholic).
Gossip aunt (a gossipmonger).
Saliva licker (sycophant, bootlicker).
Pigdog (bastard, scoundrel; also used for innerer Schweinehund - one's weaker self/inner laziness).
Slowpoke, ditherer
A face that begs to be slapped (someone very annoying or arrogant).
Recorder face (someone with a dumb or expressionless face).
Socks-in-sandals wearer (fashion faux pas, implies being uncool or a tourist).
Soft egg (wimp, coward).
Know-it-all
Chatterbox
Smart aleck, know-it-all (often for children).
Cardboard nose (fool, idiot; also a red nose worn by clowns).
Crybaby.
Scaredy-cat
Dumb head, idiot.
Horned ox (blockhead, dimwit - strong insult).
Plum (can mean wimp or loser).
Spaz (offensive, derogatory term for someone clumsy or foolish, derived from spastic). Use with extreme caution or not at all.
Chopped face (ugly person - very offensive).
Complete post (utter idiot).
Carousel brakeman (someone too stupid for any job requiring minimal brainpower; implies they slow everything down).
Fun brake (killjoy, someone who spoils the fun).
Diarrhea gargler (extremely vulgar and nonsensical insult).
Folding spade (idiot, useless person).

Term_Phrase_Item: Säufste, stirbste, säufste nich, stirbste ooch, also säufste.
notes: If you drink, you die; if you don't drink, you die too; so drink. (A fatalistic, humorous justification for drinking alcohol - Berlin).

Term_Phrase_Item: Den/Dich hamse wohl mit'n Klammerbeutel jepudert?
notes: Are you nuts? / Have you lost your mind? / Are you completely stupid? (Questioning someone's sanity or intelligence, often humorously - Berlin).

Term_Phrase_Item: Lehrer: "Wo wurde der Friedensvertrag von 1806 unterschrieben?" – Fritzchen: "Unten rechts?"
notes: (Teacher: "Where was the peace treaty of 1806 signed?" – Little Fritz: "At the bottom right?")

Term_Phrase_Item: Fritzchen fragt seine Mutter: "Mama, darf ich mit Opa Seilbahn fahren?" Mutter: "Nein, Fritzchen, der Opa wird ordentlich begraben!"
notes: (Little Fritz asks his mother: "Mom, can I go on a cable car ride with Grandpa?" Mother: "No, Fritzchen, Grandpa will be buried properly!")

Term_Phrase_Item: Fritzchen kommt nach Hause und sagt: "Mama, ich habe heute als Einziger in der Klasse eine Eins bekommen!" Fragt die Mutter: "Wirklich? In welchem Fach denn?" Fritzchen: "Beim Alkoholtest."
notes: (Little Fritz comes home and says: "Mom, today I was the only one in class to get an A!" Mother asks: "Really? In what subject?" Fritzchen: "In the alcohol test.")

Term_Phrase_Item: Alle Kinder bleiben am Abgrund stehen, nur nicht Peter, der läuft noch'n Meter.
notes: (All children stop before the gorge, only Peter walks another meter.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Alle Kinder spielen auf der Baustelle, außer Rolf, der spielt Golf.
notes: (All children play on the construction site, except Rolf, he plays golf.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Alle Kinder schauen auf das brennende Haus, nur nicht Klaus, der schaut raus.
notes: (All children look at the burning house, except Klaus, he's looking out.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Trinkt der Bauer und fährt Traktor, wird er zum Gefahrenfaktor.
notes: (If the farmer drinks and rides his tractor, he becomes a danger factor.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Kräht der Hahn auf dem Mist, ändert sich das Wetter oder es bleibt wie es ist.
notes: (If the rooster crows on the dung heap, the weather changes or it stays as it is.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Was sagt ein Krokodil, nachdem es einen Clown gefressen hat? – Schmeckt komisch!
notes: (What does a crocodile say after eating a clown? – Tastes funny!)

Term_Phrase_Item: Was ist ein Keks unterm Baum? – Ein schattiges Plätzchen.
notes: (What do you call a cookie under a tree? – A shady spot / cookie.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Warum steht ein Pils im Wald? – Weil die Tannen zapfen.
notes: (Why is there a Pils (beer) in the forest? – Because the fir trees are drawing beer / Because of the pine cones.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Treffen sich zwei Jäger. Beide tot.
notes: (Two hunters meet. Both dead.)

Term_Phrase_Item: "Ich habe heute Brotteig beim Sport mitgemacht." - "Und, wie war's?" - "Naja, ich bin nicht richtig aufgegangen."
notes: ("I took bread dough to sports class today." - "And how was it?" - "Well, I didn't really rise/get into it.")

Term_Phrase_Item: Was macht ein Clown im Büro? – Faxen.
notes: (What does a clown do in the office? – Faxen.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Sagt der Walfisch zum Thunfisch: "Was sollen wir tun, Fisch?" Sagt der Thunfisch zum Walfisch: "Du hast die Wahl, Fisch!"
notes: (Says the whale to the tuna: "What should we do, fish?" Says the tuna to the whale: "You have the choice, fish!")

Term_Phrase_Item: Was ist der Unterschied zwischen einem Saxen und einem Ausländer? Den Ausländer versteht man, wenn er Deutsch spricht.
notes: (What is the difference between a Saxon and a foreigner? You'll understand the foreigner when he speaks German. - Pokes fun at the Saxon dialect).

Term_Phrase_Item: Mami, Mami, ich will nicht in die USA!” – “Sei ruhig und schwimm weiter.”
notes: (“Mummy, mummy, I don't want to go to the USA!” – “Shut up and keep swimming.”)

Term_Phrase_Item: Kunde im Supermarkt: "Haben Sie denn gar keine Eier?" Verkäuferin: "Doch, aber die sind heute alle krankgeschrieben."
notes: (Customer in supermarket: "Don't you have any eggs at all?" Saleswoman: "Yes, but they're all on sick leave today.")

Term_Phrase_Item: Zwei Männer gehen durch die Wüste. Sagt der eine: "Lass mich mal in die Mitte."
notes: (Two men are walking through the desert. One says: "Let me walk in the middle.")

Term_Phrase_Item: Was passiert mit einem roten Stein der ins Schwarze Meer fällt? – Er wird nass.
notes: (What happens if you drop a red stone into the Black Sea? – It'll get wet.)
Fly's scrotum (Swabian - humorous term for something extremely small).
Glasses/Specs (humorous, somewhat dated).
Hangover. Also Muskelkater for sore muscles.
A pun or play on words.
A game where one word has multiple meanings, and players have to guess the word based on descriptions of its different meanings.
A pun, often a bad or obvious one (dad joke).

Term_Phrase_Item: Fischers Fritz fischt frische Fische, frische Fische fischt Fischers Fritz.
notes: (Targets f, sch [ʃ], r sounds. Fischer's Fritz fishes fresh fish, fresh fish fishes Fischer's Fritz.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Blaukraut bleibt Blaukraut und Brautkleid bleibt Brautkleid.
notes: (Targets bl, br, kr, kl clusters, au vs. ei diphthongs, l/r alternation. Red cabbage remains red cabbage and wedding dress remains wedding dress.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Zehn zahme Ziegen zogen zehn Zentner Zucker zum Zoo.
notes: (Targets z [ts] sound. Ten tame goats pulled ten hundredweights of sugar to the zoo.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Der Cottbuser Postkutscher putzt den Cottbuser Postkutschkasten.
notes: (Targets k, tsch [tʃ], s, tz [ts], p, repetition. The Cottbus stagecoach driver cleans the Cottbus stagecoach box.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Wenn Fliegen hinter Fliegen fliegen, fliegen Fliegen Fliegen nach.
notes: (Targets f, fl, g sounds, distinguishing noun from verb. When flies fly behind flies, flies fly after flies.)

Term_Phrase_Item: In Ulm, um Ulm, und um Ulm herum.
notes: (Targets l, m sounds. In Ulm, around Ulm, and all around Ulm.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Acht alte Ameisen aßen am Abend Ananas.
notes: (Or: Achtzig alte Ameisen aßen am Abend achtzig Ananas.) (Targets vowel 'a' [a:] sound. Eight old ants ate pineapple in the evening. / Eighty old ants ate eighty pineapples in the evening.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Die Katzen kratzen im Katzenkasten, im Katzenkasten kratzen Katzen.
notes: (Targets k, tz [ts], r sounds. The cats scratch in the cat box, in the cat box scratch cats.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Im dichten Fichtendickicht sind dicke Fichten wichtig.
notes: (Targets d, ch [ç], t, k clusters. In the dense spruce thicket, thick spruces are important.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Zwischen zwei Zwetschgenzweigen zwitschern zwei Schwalben.
notes: (Targets z [ts], w [v], sch [ʃ], tsch [tʃ] sounds. Between two plum branches chirp two swallows.)
(Targets b, r clusters, au [aʊ] diphthong. Beer brewer Bauer brews brown beer.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Es klapperten die Klapperschlangen bis ihre Klappern schlapper klangen.
notes: (Targets kl, p, r, sch [ʃ], l sounds, rhyme. The rattlesnakes rattled until their rattles sounded weaker.)
(Extremely long compound word - Note: "Hottentot" is an outdated/offensive term for the Khoikhoi people. This is more of a word puzzle.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Graben Grabengräber Gruben? Graben Grubengräber Gräben? Nein! Grabengräber graben Gräben. Grubengräber graben Gruben.
notes: (Targets g, r, b sounds, similar words, logical puzzle. Do ditch diggers dig pits? Do pit diggers dig ditches? No! Ditch diggers dig ditches. Pit diggers dig pits.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Bürsten mit schwarzen Borsten bürsten besser als Bürsten mit weißen Borsten.
notes: (Targets b, r, s, t, sch [ʃ] sounds; ü [y] vs. o [ɔ] vowels. Brushes with black bristles brush better than brushes with white bristles.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Ob er über Oberammergau, oder aber über Unterammergau, oder ob er überhaupt nicht kommt, ist nicht gewiss.
notes: (Targets o, u, au, ei vowels; b, r consonants; long sentence. Whether he comes via Oberammergau, or via Unterammergau, or whether he doesn't come at all, is not certain.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Schnecken erschrecken, wenn sie an Schnecken schlecken, weil zum Schrecken vieler Schnecken Schnecken nicht schmecken.
notes: (Targets sch [ʃ], n, k, l sounds, repetition, complex sentence. Snails get scared when they lick snails, because to the horror of many snails, snails don't taste good.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Wir Wiener Waschweiber würden weiße Wäsche waschen, wenn wir wüssten, wo warmes Wasser wäre.
notes: (Targets w [v], sch [ʃ], s sounds, vowel variety. We Viennese washerwomen would wash white laundry if we knew where warm water was.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Wenn du Wachsmasken magst, Max macht Wachsmasken aus Wachsmaskenwachs.
notes: (Targets w [v], k, s, x [ks] sounds. If you like wax masks, Max makes wax masks from wax mask wax.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Der faule Paul klaut blaue Pflaumen vom Baum.
notes: (Lazy Paul steals blue plums from the tree.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Lang schwang der Klang am Hang entlang.
notes: (Long swung the sound along the slope.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Furcht vor Fruchtfleisch führt zu Flucht vor Fruchtfleisch.
notes: (Fear of fruit pulp leads to flight from fruit pulp.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Jedes Jahr im Juli essen Julia und Jens Johannisbeeren.
notes: (Every year in July, Julia and Jens eat currants.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Kluge kleine Katzen kratzen keine Krokodile.
notes: (Variation: Kluge kleine Katzen kratzen keine Krokodile, sondern kluge kleine Katzen kratzen kahle Kinnbacken. - Clever little cats don't scratch crocodiles; instead, clever little cats scratch bald chins.) (Clever little cats don't scratch crocodiles.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Müller, mahl mir mein Mehl, meine Mutter will mir heute Mehlbrei machen.
notes: (Miller, grind my flour for me, my mother wants to make me flour porridge today.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Drei bärtige Reiter reiten rasend über graue Berge.
notes: (Three bearded riders ride furiously over grey mountains.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Müller Lümmer frühstückt schüsselweise grünes Gemüse.
notes: (Miller Lümmer eats bowlfuls of green vegetables for breakfast.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Dem Müllmann sein Mümmelmann mümmelt an dem Müll dran. An dem Müll dran mümmelt der Mümmelmann vom Müllmann.
notes: (The garbage man's bunny nibbles on the trash. On the trash nibbles the bunny of the garbage man. Mümmelmann is a colloquial term for a rabbit, mümmeln means to nibble.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Einsame Esel essen nasse Nesseln nicht, nasse Nesseln essen einsame Esel nicht.
notes: (Lonely donkeys don't eat wet nettles, wet nettles are not eaten by lonely donkeys.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Biberacher Bierbrauer brauen beständig braunes Biberacher Bockbier.
notes: (Beer brewers from Biberach consistently brew brown Bock beer from Biberach.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Ein Soldat mit stumpfen Stiefeln saß auf einem spitzen Stein und starrte stundenlang die stillen stummen Sternlein an.
notes: (A soldier with blunt boots sat on a pointy rock and stared at the silent, mute little stars for hours.)
(Gudrun's turkey is resting well.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Griesbrei bleibt Griesbrei, und Kriegsbeil bleibt Kriegsbeil.
notes: (Semolina pudding stays semolina pudding, and a battle axe stays a battle axe.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Zwei Astronauten kauten und kauten während sie blaugrüne Mondsteine klaubten.
notes: (Two astronauts chewed and chewed while they collected blue-green moonstones.)

Term_Phrase_Item: Der Kaplan klebt klappbare Pappplakate an die klappbare Kapellwand.
notes: (The chaplain sticks foldable cardboard posters onto the foldable chapel wall.)
Yes and no (blend of ja and nein, expresses indecision/uncertainty).
Crap / Darn (expresses mild annoyance or disappointment).
Well / I guess / Oh well (softens a statement or introduces slight disagreement/resignation).
Ah, I see! / Oh, right! (expresses understanding).
Exactly / Precisely.
Exactly / Just so / My point.
Just / Simply (often untranslatable, adds emphasis or indicates something is just the way it is).
Yes (used to contradict a negative statement or question).
Man! / Gosh! (expresses surprise, exasperation, or sympathy).
Wow! / Whoa! (expresses surprise, amazement, or being overwhelmed).
Well, now! / What's this? (expresses mild surprise).
Well... / Oh well... (expresses resignation, contemplation, or that there's nothing to be done).
Oh! / Uh oh! (expresses surprise or realization of a problem).
Phew! (expresses relief or exhaustion).
So to speak / As it were / Quasi.
Right? / Isn't it? (Tag question, especially Southern Germany for gelle).
Thank God!
Damn!
Good heavens! / Wow!
auf dem (on the - contraction, Berlin and other regions)
Weißt du? / Verstehst du? (You know? / Understand? - Common tag question, Berlin reduction)
Mach's gut (Take care - Eastern German pronunciation/reduction)
ein / einen (a/an)
eine (a/an)
haben (to have)
sind wir / sagen wir (are we / say we)
gibt es (there is/are)
hast du (do you have)
kannst du (can you)
schau mal (look)
ist es (is it)
haben wir (do we have)
wollen wir (do we want)
Characteristic attitude of Berliners (direct, quick-witted, often gruff but good-hearted, dry/sarcastic humor).
Beer for the road (beer purchased to be enjoyed while walking or on public transport - Berlin concept, but practiced elsewhere too).
Colloquial form of German spoken by young people in multicultural neighborhoods, incorporating elements of Turkish, Arabic, etc.
Mullet hairstyle
Person from former East Germany (term reflecting historical division, can be derogatory or neutral depending on context).
Person from former West Germany (term reflecting historical division, can be derogatory or neutral depending on context).
Traditional Hamburg greeting and response ritual.
Apple wine (regional specialty and cultural touchstone in Hesse).
Specific type of pitcher for apple wine (Hesse).
Special type of glass for apple wine (Hesse).
Earworm (a song that gets stuck in your head).
Storm-free (when you have the house to yourself, especially parents being away).
A face that begs to be slapped (see also Insults).
Glove snowball thrower (a wimp, someone who is overly cautious - humorous).
Three cheeses high (a small child, often used affectionately or slightly mockingly for someone short).
Language feeling (an intuitive grasp of a language, a knack for languages).
Malicious joy (pleasure derived from someone else's misfortune).
Far-sickness (a longing for distant places, wanderlust; the opposite of Heimweh - homesickness).
To make something worse by trying to improve it.
Inner pig-dog (one's weaker self, the voice that encourages laziness or procrastination).
Explanation distress (being put on the spot and struggling to quickly explain oneself or a situation).
Gate-closing panic (fear of missing out as opportunities diminish with age).
World-pain (a feeling of melancholy and weariness with the world).
Grief bacon/blubber (excess weight gained from emotional overeating).
Move-compulsion (a situation where one is forced to make a move, and any move is disadvantageous).
Slipper hero (a man who is henpecked).
Hodgepodge, mess, chaos.
A strong desire to travel and explore the world (borrowed into English).
Fingertip feeling (intuition, tact, delicate handling of a situation).
External shame (to feel embarrassed for someone else, vicarious embarrassment).
Sour pickle time (the off-season, news lull, dog days of summer).
Springtime lethargy (a temporary feeling of tiredness or lassitude in spring).
Honey-cake horse (to grin like a Cheshire cat, to beam broadly and foolishly).
A feeling of security, safety, warmth, comfort, and peace.
Head cinema (vividly imagining a scenario).
Thought carousel (when thoughts keep spinning in one's head, overthinking).
End of the workday (celebratory feeling of finishing work).
Schnapps idea (a crazy or ill-thought-out idea).
Forest loneliness (a feeling of solitude and peacefulness in a forest).
Spirit of the age (the defining mood or spirit of a particular period of history).
Double-goer (a look-alike or double of a living person).
Nonsense, humbug (can also refer to a bogeyman figure).
A confirmed bachelor (often with a slightly melancholic or eccentric connotation).
A small treat (like a sweet) eaten before going to bed (Southern Germany/Austria).
Rascal, rowdy, boisterous (often for children).
To have silly ideas or bees in one's bonnet
Knowing one's people, often in a slightly resigned or knowing way. From Schiller's "Wallenstein."
A regulars' table in a pub, often associated with opinionated discussions.

Term_Phrase_Item: Ick sitze da und esse Klops...
notes: Opening line of a famous, nonsensical Berlin rhyme/song ("Klopslied") - Iconic cultural reference. (Klops = meatball).
Viral rap song based on a tongue twister about Barbara's rhubarb bar, created by Berlin musicians - Modern cultural reference.
Traditional Hamburg greeting ritual - Local cultural reference.
In Hamburg, refers almost exclusively to the Reeperbahn, the city's famous nightclub district - Specific regional cultural reference tied to a word.
The Rhineland's (especially Cologne, Mainz, Düsseldorf) lively culture and Carnival celebrations influence slang and local customs (Alaaf, Helau, Kamelle, Bützje).
The significance of apple wine in Hessian culture is reflected in local slang and dedicated paraphernalia (Bembel, Geripptes).
The world's largest Volksfest, held annually in Munich, Bavaria. Influences Bavarian culture, beer consumption, and traditional attire (Dirndl, Lederhosen, Maß).
"Crime Scene" - a very popular and long-running German/Austrian/Swiss TV crime series, with different cities and detective teams. A Sunday evening ritual for many.
"The Program with the Mouse" - an iconic children's television series, known for its educational segments ("Lach- und Sachgeschichten").
Small animated characters that appear in commercial breaks on the ZDF television channel.
"Little Sandman" - a beloved children's bedtime television program, with different versions in former East and West Germany that continue today.
The symbolic figure on pedestrian traffic lights in former East Germany, now a cult figure and popular souvenir.
A style of popular music with sentimental lyrics and catchy tunes, very popular in Germany. Artists like Helene Fischer, Andrea Berg.
Internationally famous German Neue Deutsche Härte band, known for their controversial lyrics and elaborate stage shows.
Pioneering German electronic music band.
Germany's most famous classical writers, often quoted or referenced.
The German Beer Purity Law of 1516.
The German highway system, famous for having sections with no speed limits.
Hello (widely recognized, less formal than Guten Tag).
Cutesy, very informal version of Hallo.
Hey / What's up? / Well? (very casual, often used among close acquaintances to initiate conversation or as a response).
Hello (Northern Germany, used throughout the day).
Playful variation of Moin (Northern Germany).
Greeting (North Rhine-Westphalia and other regions, short for Guten Tag, used at any time).
Hello / Goodbye (Bavaria and Austria, versatile).
Hello (Southern Germany, especially Bavaria, and Austria; lit. Greet God).
Hello (Swiss German).
Bye (most popular informal farewell).
More casual/playful variation of Tschüss.
Have a good one / Take care (common and friendly farewell).
See you then / See you later.
See you soon.
Bye (borrowed from Italian, common).
Farewell (Southern Germany, especially Swabia; also Austria).
Good Day / Hello (Berlin accent version of Guten Tag).
Hello (Swabia, Bavaria - informal, singular 'you' / plural 'you').
Hi! (Swabia, influenced by French "Salut").
Hello (Hesse and Rhineland, used at any time).
Goodbye (Hesse, casual).
See you around!
We'll speak soon! (Often used in a business context for "talk to you later").
Go for it! / Take care! / Bye! (very informal).
Goodbye and God bless (Bavaria, more formal than Pfiati).
Little day (cutesy/informal hello).
Bro / Man / Pal / Buddy (addressing close friends, Berlin, more prevalent in Wedding district).
Bro / Man / Pal / Buddy (addressing close friends, Berlin, favored in Zehlendorf area, can imply closer bond than Keule).
Mate / Bro (close male friends, Northern Germany and widely used, Digga gaining popularity through hip-hop).
Bro / Dude (Youth slang, from German rap).
Dude / Bro (Popular among youth across Germany, including Berlin. Can also express surprise or annoyance).
(Freches) Mädchen ((cheeky/sassy) girl - can be a term of address, sometimes dismissive, sometimes affectionate).
Treasure / Little treasure (common term of endearment for partners, children, close friends).
Mouse / Little mouse (common term of endearment, similar to Schatz).
Bunny / Little bunny (common term of endearment).
Darling / Sweetheart.
Sweetie (female/male).
Pearl (can be used for a girlfriend or a generally great woman, sometimes Hamburg-specific for a good soul).
Little brother / little sister (affectionate, can be used for close friends too).
Boss (can be used playfully to address someone in charge or even a friend who is being bossy).
Angel / Little angel.
Sunshine.
Heart-leaf (sweetheart, darling - somewhat old-fashioned but still used).
Cute, sweet term of endearment, can be a bit cutesy/kitschy.
Sparrow / Little sparrow (often for children).
